content:
Just got this in a clash and I won after 8 minutes of coding (even though I'd solved this twice as a reviewer).

Everyone else in the clash got 0%. 7/8 clashers. :(
I still think it is just too hard for a clash.

https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/4173778b04d6517e098cc1cac48404d70bfe65d

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle that requires some prior reading / knowledge. The modifications to the actual electron configuration rules make the puzzle simple enough to understand and implement.
The orbital order and the maximum orbital capacity are integrated into the IDE and removed from the input.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Although i was considering rejecting due to its complexity, i believe strong programmers will be able to see the solution clearly within the time duration of a CoC. The challenge is well made and well thought through, it has a good concept.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ce sujet mêle habilement programmation et chimie, mais gagnerait en accessibilité avec une brève analogie visuelle du remplissage des orbitales. L'algorithme est simple, mais la terminologie pourrait rebuter les non-initiés. Une contextualisation enfantine du principe d'Aufbau rendrait l'exercice plus engageant tout en conservant sa valeur pédagogique : des boîtes ou des tiroirs d'une commode portant des noms (1s, 2s, etc..) serait peut-être plus appréciable.
Mais sinon, je trouve que ce sujet correspond totalement à un CoC, bien qu'il puisse sembler un peu difficile à aborder. Il se résout ensuite assez facilement en utilisant les collections semblables aux dictionnaires !

Cool idea for a puzzle. I appreciate that you indicated the atomic numbers where the special rule applies.

Although this problem is doable, the fact that your solution is 20+ lines of code seems indicative that this problem is too difficult for the fastest game mode, let alone the shortest game mode. I do have some prior chemistry knowledge which makes it easier for me but way harder for those who have to spend a minute or two just reading the problem statement.

I would encourage you to instead consider the reverse puzzle, where your input provides the electron configuration and you require the total number of electrons as output instead. This way, the player need not know about all the different conventions and special rules and can instead focus on the suffix of each orbital configuration.

If you want to make it harder, you can consider providing the condensed electron configuration instead.

Honestly, this would be a cool puzzle, but it's way too hard for clash of code.
I spent 15 minutes on it and could only JUST solve up to "Exceptions" in that time. I gave up on the exceptions.
There's no way anyone is solving this in 5 minutes... reading all of the statement alone takes 5 minutes.

This is coming from someone with a degree in quantum science, lol. I think you should maybe submit this as a puzzle instead. If you also want to have a clash version then it needs to be way simpler:
1. Get rid of the string formatting "H = ....", just allow the answer to be the electron configuration and the input to be the atomic number (no symbols). e.g. 1 -> "1s1", 4 -> "1s2 2s2". It might even be better to not have "n" elements per test and just have one element per test.

2. Get rid of the exceptions, it's way beyond the level of a clash to learn about how transition metals behave... I would just put a note saying that the atomic number will never be 24, 29, 42 or 47.

3. Get rid of the long examples or at least the 2nd one. Having a really long statement scares clashers off and they usually end up just submitting nothing for 0%, assuming that the clash is too hard for them.

I think with those changes, it would be a fun clash. Still very hard to solve in 5 minutes, but possibly doable.

Otherwise, this is a great 'easy' puzzle, imo. I suggest you submit this version as a puzzle and then if you feel up for it, edit this to a simpler version for a clash.
I have been trying for well over 5 minutes, and I can't solve the transition metals. Other than that, it's probably just me being new to Java, this is an amazing contribution!
It might take some time to understand at the beginning especially for people not familiar with chemistry like me but the puzzle is interesting and instructive.
That's a good idea to add some physic-chemistry on clash of code. Hope your contribution will be approved in future

Goal
* You may remove the two sentences above "Example" to avoid repetition.

* "Find the atomic number of Krypton (Kr) which has an atomic number of 36.": Please simplify the sentence to avoid repeating "atomic number".

* Example: Suggest to add one more example to illustrate the case of 24, 29, 42 or 47.

Output
* Please format the equal sign (EXCLUDING the quotation marks) as a {{constant}}.

All sections
* Is it more accurate to say "electron configuration", instead of "spectroscopic notation"?

Thanks.
Appreciate your feedback. Does it look better now?
Thank you for your feedback
Thank you for your feedback!

Thank you for your feedback! Unfortunately, I only know python so I’m unable to help you. 

However, I believe there are more Java coders who would be more than happy to help!

You are right. The exceptions are making this clash harder. However, I believe this is too easy for puzzle. 

Please allow me to collect more feedback regarding the difficulty of this clash, and I will remove the exceptions if a lot of people thinks it’s too hard for clash of code. 

I’ll still keep the string formatting to maintain the difficulty of this clash. 

Thank you for your feedback.
Hello! Thank you for your feedback. I have simplified the problem so the stability rule is not applied to this problem. Hopefully, that will make this problem more doable.
Hello, I have removed the exceptions and shortened the statement. Hopefully that makes it easier!

It's definitely better now.
I just tried it again and solved it in 10 minutes, but of course this time I didn't have to read as much.

I certainly couldn't approve it, since I can't even solve it in 5 minutes on a second try. I'm sure I'm coding it in a slow way, but still it seems like there's a lot of steps to solve in 5 minutes.

I think others will probably be willing to approve it though, but I suspect it will have a lot of 0% submissions in live clashes.
Yes. You may want to update the last line of the stub generator too.
oops forgot about that. Should be fine now
